The Philippine Legislature rejected the Howes-Cutting Plan for Philippine independence on the grounds that the legislation was a tariff against Philippine products and an immigration bill against Philippine labor and not a credible independence plan.

President Harmodio Arias of Panama met with President Franklin Roosevelt in Washington to discuss relations between the two countries. The two governments released a declaration whereby Panama would control all of the commercial rights within the Canal Zone and the U.S. agreed that there should not be any American enterprise which was detrimental to Panama. This agreement marked increasing Panamanian nationalism in relation to the question of sovereignty over the Panama Canal.
U.S. Rejection of Membership in World Court

Although President Franklin Roosevelt urged Congress to ratify the World Court treaty and make the U.S. a member of the organization, the Senate rejected the proposal by a vote of 52-35. The Hearst newspapers and the radio addresses by Father Charles Coughlin kept the Irreconcilables on track and opposed to participation in international organizations.
U.S. Approval of Philippine Constitution Draft
President Franklin D. Roosevelt approved the draft of the Philippine constitution, a document which resulted from a constitutional convention.

The Liberian Legislature ratified an agreement with American financial interests by which interest payments on the loan of 1926 was reduced to five percent and all payments would be made dependent on the size of Liberia's revenue. The Roosevelt administration resumed diplomatic relations with Monrovia. The rapid development of the Firestone rubber plantations secured greater revenue for the Liberian government which allowed the country to resume interest and amortization payments.

President Franklin Roosevelt announced that Under Secretary of State Sumner Welles would travel to Europe to determine the war aims of the belligerent powers and to determine the possibility of negotiating a just and lasting peace. Under Secretary Welles issued his report to the president on March 28th.
USA reaction on Paris falling into German hands

While Parisians who remained trapped in their capital despaired, French men and women in the west cheered-as Canadian troops rolled through their region, offering hope for a free France yet. The United States did not remain completely idle, though. On this day, President Roosevelt froze the American assets of the Axis powers, Germany and Italy.
Non-Transfer Corollary to the Monroe Doctrine

The U.S. Department of State notified European governments that the United States would not recognize the transfer of any geographic region of the Western Hemisphere from one non-American power to another non-American power. The United States sought to prevent German access to French and Dutch colonies in the Americas.
President Franklin Roosevelt named Henry Stimson the new Secretary of War and Frank Knox the new Secretary of the Navy.
President Franklin Roosevelt named Henry Stimson the new Secretary of War and Frank Knox the new Secretary of the Navy.

The U.S. Congress passed the Smith Act designed to strengthen existing laws regarding the admission and deportation of aliens in the United States. The law was designed to check subversive activities in the U.S. and made it unlawful for anyone to advocate or teach the overthrow or destruction of any U.S. government by force or violence or to be a member of a group that advocated such goals.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Canadian Prime Minister Mackenzie King met and agreed to set up a Joint Board of Defense to coordinate U.S. and Canadian defense efforts.

The Roosevelt administration expanded the Pittman Act by authorizing the Export-Import Bank to lend American republics up to $500 million and to permit these countries to acquire munitions up to a total value of $400 million for their defenses.
The Roosevelt administration announced that 16.4 million American men had registered for the military draft as the first step towards expanding U.S. military forces.

U.S. Secretary of War Henry Stimson and British Minister of Supply Sir Walter Layton agreed to a partial standardization of British and American military weapons and equipment. The agreement established a general policy of pooling British and American technical knowledge, patents, and formulas for weapons production.

President Franklin Roosevelt recommended Lend-Lease assistance to the Allies and enunciated the 'Four Freedoms' (freedom of speech and expression, freedom of worship, freedom from want, and freedom from fear) as the basis for a post-war peace in his annual message to Congress.

American and British military officials met secretly in Washington, DC and developed the ABC-1 plan, outlining a common Anglo-American strategy for World War II. Both countries agreed that in the event of war with both Germany and Japan, the concentration of force should be directed against the Germans.
U.S. Fleet Assets in the Caribbean

The Roosevelt administration raised the status of the United States Patrol Force in the Caribbean to fleet status and enhanced the resources in the region. The U.S. Navy developed naval facilities in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba  San Juan, Puerto Rico  and St. Thomas, Virgin Islands at a rapid pace. The U.S. also planned a third set of locks for the Panama Canal.
The Panamanian government granted the United States the right to extend American air defenses beyond the limits of the Canal Zone.

Facing mounting losses to Allied shipping from German air, surface, and submarine forces, President Franklin Roosevelt informed British Prime Minister that the U.S. would extend its security zone and patrol areas to a line covering all North Atlantic waters west of West Longitude 26 degrees, the 'sea frontier of the U.S.

President Franklin Roosevelt warned Admiral Nomura, the Japanese ambassador to the United States, that the U.S. would be forced to take immediate action to safeguard American rights and interests in the Far East if the Japanese took new military actions in the region.
President Franklin Roosevelt signed a law which permitted the U.S. Army to keep draftees in service 18 months longer.
British Pledge in the U.S.-Japanese War
In the event that negotiations failed and the United States became involved in a war with the Japanese, Prime Minister Winston Churchill pledged British military aid to the U.S.

Owing to the overextension of British anti-submarine assets protecting Atlantic convoys, the U.S. Navy announced that American destroyers and anti-submarine forces would protect convoys as far east as Iceland. The Royal Navy would assume responsibility for the protection of the convoys from Iceland to British ports.
To provide for $3.6 billion for defense appropriations, a revenue measure became law in the United States.
President Franklin Roosevelt asked Congress to modify the neutrality laws to allow American merchant ships to be armed and to allow their passage through combat zones.
President Franklin Roosevelt privately proposed to British Prime Minister Winston Churchill that the countries pool their resources and research facilities to develop an atomic bomb.

In response to German U-boot attacks on American warships in the North Atlantic, Congress revised the restrictive clauses of the neutrality laws and authorized the arming of U.S. merchant ships. In addition, American cargo ships were permitted to carry supplies to belligerent ports.

The governments reached an agreement on the Mexican appropriation of American oil company property. The Mexicans agreed to pay $40 million to settle American agrarian claims. In return, the U.S. government established a $40 million fund to support the Mexican peso, to resume the purchase of Mexican silver above the world market price. Both governments agreed to appoint an expert to determine an equitable valuation of the U.S. owned oil companies that had operated in Mexico.

In the wake of the Great Depression, Congress passed the Securities Exchange Act of 1933, which mandated that all securites trading involve accurate and timely disclosure, in order to protect investors and ensure fair dealings.
Good, we need to keep these bankers honest.

As a followup to the 1933 act, Congress passed the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. While the 1933 act regulated the primary market, in which companies buy and sell securities between each other, the 1934 regulated secondary trading individuals, brokers, and dealers. In addition, the act also established the Securities and Exchange Commission to oversee the financial sector.
Good, we need to keep these bankers honest.

A foundational statute of US labor law, the National Labor Relations Act guaranteed basic rights of private sector employees to organize into trade unions, engage in collective bargaining, and take collective action including strike if necessary. It also established the National Labor Relations Act, which conducts elections for union representation, and investigates unfair labor practices.

Social Security Act was drafted during Franklin Delano Roosevelt's first term by the President's Committee on Economic Security, under Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, and passed by Congress as part of the Second New Deal. The act was an attempt to limit what were seen as dangers in the modern American life, including old age, poverty, unemployment, and the burdens of widows and fatherless children.

On March 16, 1936, warmer than normal temperatures led to the melting of snow and ice on the upper Allegheny and Monongahela rivers. These rivers and their tributaries were already over their banks and were threatening the city of Pittsburgh. On March 17, 1936 the waters reached flood stage of 25 feet. Heavy rains overnight caused the waters to rise quickly, and on March 18, the water peaked at about at 46 feet, 21 feet above flood stage.

A Heat Wave has struck the Continental United States and Canada the most severe heat wave in the Modern History of North America. 'The Great Heat Wave' started in late June went up over 100°F (38°C) as the Drought conditions worsened due to a lack of rain. Now into July the heat has reached all time records. In Steele North Dakota temperatures reached 121°F (50°C). In Ohio temperatures reached 110°F (43°C) which was close to tying a record high set in 1934.

The Triborough Bridge is a complex of three separate bridges in New York City.It connects the boroughs of Manhattan, Queens, and the Bronx via Randalls and Wards Islands. The total cost of the bridge was more than $60 million, one of the largest public works projects of the Great Depression, more expensive even than the Hoover Dam.
At the summer olympics Jessie Owens won 4 gold medals!
The San FranciscoOakland Bay Bridge is a complex of bridges spanning San Francisco Bay, connecting San Francisco and Oakland.
There will never be a better bridge in San Francisco

On December 30, 1936, the fledging United Automobile Workers (UAW) union began a sit-down strike at the Fisher # 1 General Motors Plant in Flint, Michigan. Occupying theplant until March of nest year. In breaking with the usual  pattern, the strike was successful, as GM and UAW representatives reached an agreement. The strike gave the UAW instant legitimacy. The next year, the union's membership grew from 30,000 to 50,000 workers.
The strike was heard 'round the world

The New London School explosion occurred on March 18, 1937, when a natural gas leak caused an explosion, destroying the London School of New London, Texas. The disaster killed more than 295 students and teachers, making it the deadliest school disaster in American history

Between November 1944 and April 1945, Japan launched over 9,300 Fu-Go, or fire balloons at the United States. The balloons were designed to use the jet stream over the Pacific Ocean and wreak havoc on Canadian and American cities, forests, and farmland. They carried loads varying from a 12-kilogram (26 lb) incendiary to one 15 kg (33 lb) antipersonnel bomb and four 5 kg (11 lb) incendiary devices attached About 300 balloon bombs were found or observed in North America, killing six people and causing a small amount of damage.
We need to keep this out of the papers so as not to cause a panic.

On July 17, 1944, at the Port Chicago Naval Magazine in Port Chicago, California, United States, Munitions detonated while being loaded onto a cargo vessel bound  the remaining three served additional months in prison. The case turned it into a cause célèbre, and it and other race-related Navy protests of 19441945 led the Navy to change its practices and initiate the desegregation of its forces beginning in February 1946.for the Pacific, killing 320 sailors and civilians and injuring 390 others. Most of the dead and injured were enlisted African-American sailors. A month later, continuing unsafe conditions inspired hundreds of servicemen to refuse to load munitions, an act known as the Port Chicago Mutiny. Fifty mencalled the "Port Chicago 50" -were convicted of mutiny and sentenced to long prison terms. Forty-seven of the 50 were released in January 1946

The disastrous invasion of Finland of 1940 showed not only Stalin but most importantly Hitler and his Generals the weak condition of the Soviet military. Urgent measures to reform the Red Army needed to be taken especially considering the growing German threat.
The Soviets Change Turkish Place Names
The Soviet government changes Turkish place names to Russian in the Crimea.
Garrison units have been formed in Sevastopol in order to halt the enemy advance.
Garrison units have been formed in Krasnodar in order to halt the enemy advance.
Garrison units have been formed in Rostov in order to halt the enemy advance.

As enemy troops pushed closer to the capital of the USSR, the communist party mobilized its enormous human resources. Half a million civilians were used in the construction of a wide defensive perimeter in front of the city, and tens of thousands of workers were organized into Garrison units by the Opolchenye. Within a month Moscow was turned into an inexpugnable fortress.

The 1st Guards Zvenigorod-Bucharest Red Banner Order of Suvorov Airborne Division was formed in accordance with an order from 8 December 1942 from the 4th Airborne Corps headquarters and the 1st Airborne Brigade. The division fought in the Battle of the Dnieper, the Battle of the KorsunCherkassy Pocket, the UmanBoto?ani Offensive, the JassyKishinev Offensive, the Battle of Debrecen, the Siege of Budapest and the Prague Offensive. In August 1945 it was sent east and fought in the Soviet invasion of Manchuria. The division became the 124th Guards Rifle Division in November 1945 and disbanded in 1956.

The 10th Rifle Division 'Stalingrad' of the Order of Lenin of the Internal Troops of the NKVD of the USSRwas a Soviet rifle division formed on February 1, 1942 prior to the Battle of Stalingrad during the Great Patriotic War and participated in heavy front-line actions which would significantly reduce its strength by the battle's end. It was under the jurisdiction of the Internal Troops of the NKVD but took strategic orders from the 62nd Army command. Later it converted into a regular Red Army division and was renamed the 181st "Order of Lenin" "Stalingrad" Rifle Division.

The activity emerged after the Nazi German Operation Barbarossa during World War II, it was coordinated and controlled by the Soviet government and modelled on that of the Red Army. The primary objective of the guerrilla warfare waged by the Soviet partisan units was the disruption of the Eastern Front's German rear, especially road and rail communications. There were also regular military formations called partisans, that were used to conduct long-range reconnaissance patrol missions behind Axis lines from the Soviet-held territory.

The extent of support for the partisan movement varied according to region and nationality, reflecting the existential concerns of the local population and authorities. The first partisan uprising occurred in Croatia on 22 June 1941, when forty Croatian Communists staged an uprising in the Brezovica woods between Sisak and Zagreb. An uprising occurred in Serbia two weeks later led by Tito (Uzice Republic), but it was quickly defeated by the Axis forces and support for the partisans in Serbia thereafter dropped.\n \nPartisan numbers from Serbia would be diminished until 1943 when the partisan movement gained an upswing by spreading the fight against the Axis. An increase of the number of partisans in Serbia, similarly to other republics, came partly in response to Tito's offer of amnesty to all collaborators on 17 August 1944. At that point, tens of thousands of Chetniks switched sides to the partisans. The amnesty would be offered again after German withdrawal from Belgrade on 21 November, 1944 and on 15 January, 1945.
China was awarded a lot of victory point provinces when the sino-japanese war began to avoid any early annexation. Since China has been defeated now, these provinces loose their victory points.

The 1939 Battle of Warsaw was fought between the Polish Warsaw Army  garrisoned and entrenched in the capital of Poland and the German Army. It started with huge aerial bombardments by the Luftwaffe starting on September 1, 1939. Land fighting started on September 8, when the first German armored units reached the Wola area and south-western suburbs of the city. Despite German radio broadcasts claiming to have captured Warsaw, the attack was stopped and soon afterwards Warsaw was placed under siege. The siege lasted until September 28, when the Polish garrison under General Walerian Czuma capitulated. The following day approximately 100,000 Polish soldiers left the city and were taken as prisoners of war. On October 1 the Wehrmacht entered Warsaw, which started a period of German occupation that lasted until the Warsaw Uprising and later until January 17, 1945. Just before the outbreak of World War II, general Fritsch was recalled, and chose to personally inspect the front lines as the 'Honorary Colonel of the 12th Artillery Regiment' during the Invasion of Poland, a very unusual activity for someone of his rank. On 22 September 1939, in Praga during the Siege of Warsaw, a Polish bullet (either a machine gun or a sharpshooter) tore an artery in his leg and he died soon after the event.

Waves of Luftwaffe bombers and Stuka dive bombers bombed Belgrade, killing 2,271 people as officially registered soon afterwards, but probably more in fact, anything between 5,000 to 10,000, and thousands of buildings were destroyed. Wehrmacht forces occupied the capital of Yugoslavia, although fighting continued across the kingdom. Partisan units took up a guerilla war against the Germans and their Yugoslav allies.

During the invasion of Greece, German troops marched into Athens while the British evacuated their Greek Expeditionary Force. While the Royal Navy was able to evacuate 48,000 of the 60,000 man force, the British again had to abandon their military equipment.
Dissolution of Nationalist Party in Syria

The National Party was a group that led the struggle against the Ottomans in Syria. They make up the National Bloc under the French and sent a delegation to France, to demand independence in 1936. The French administration in Syria dissolved the Nationalist Party due to widespread political disorder. The Syrians responded with violent street-fighting in most cities and the French proclaimed martial law in an attempt to regain control of the situation.

Leon Blum organized the first Popular Front government, composed of Socialists and Radical Socialists, with the support of French Communists. It introduced a wide program of social reforms. The rapid increase in production costs resulted in rising prices and the franc fell as capital fled the country in large amounts. It also began a massive rearmament program to modernize the military and the state had to begin a major fortification project on the Belgian frontier after they declared their neutrality.

To the east, the German Army Group B invaded and subdued the Netherlands and advanced westward through Belgium. In response, the Supreme Allied Commander, French General Maurice Gamelin, initiated Plan D which relied heavily on the Maginot Line fortifications. Gamelin committed the forces under his command. On 14 May, German Army Group A burst through the Ardennes and advanced rapidly to the west toward Sedan, then turned northward to the English Channel, in what Generalfeldmarschall Erich von Manstein called the Sickle Cut, effectively flanking the Allied forces. A series of Allied counter-attacksincluding the Battle of Arrasfailed to sever the German spearhead, which reached the coast on 20 May, separating the British Expeditionary Force near Armentieres, the French 1st Army, and the Belgian Army further to the north from the majority of French troops south of the German penetration. After reaching the Channel, the Germans swung north along the coast, threatening to capture the ports and trap the British and French forces before they could evacuate to Britain.In one of the most widely-debated decisions of the war, the Germans halted their advance on Dunkirk. The army were to halt for three days, giving the Allies time to organise an evacuation and build a defensive line. Despite the Allies' gloomy estimates of the situation, with Britain discussing a conditional surrender to Germany, in the end over 330,000 Allied troops were rescued.

Pope Pius XI died at the height of European tensions between fascism, communism, and democracy. Pius IX gained an international reputation for standing firm against any regime which threatened religion or the rights of the individual. As a result, his policies often challenged the Communists and the Fascists.

In response to the Czechoslovak government's outright rejection of the Karlsbad Program, Konrad Henlein made visits to London and Berlin. Political disorders broke out. Rumors of German troops on the border convinced the Czechoslovak government to mobilize 400,000 men. In light of the strong initial Anglo-French stand to defend Czechoslovak sovereignty, the German government accelerated the construction of fortifications on the Western frontier and ordered an expansion of the Luftwaffe.
Let's employ 500,000 men working 24-hours a day!
President Franklin Roosevelt established the National Defense Research Committee under the direction of Dr. Vannevar Bush to help plan and organize American defense preparations.

The Bulgarian government threw its support behind the Axis powers and German troops marched into Sofia. The British diplomatic corps withdrew from Sofia on February 24th, and the Soviet government warned the Bulgarians not to expect Russian assistance.
The Argentinean government declared the Communist Party illegal. This move reflected the growing power of the Right in the country.

In spite of the election victory of the Left in the Venezuelan Congress, the government arrested many of the leaders of leftist parties, including newly elected congressmen, on the charge of Communism. Most of the leaders were exiled and many radical organizations were dissolved.

The Agrarian Party, led by Kyosti Kallio, won the Finnish national elections with the support of the Social Democrats. President Kallio formed a coalition government, composed of Agrarians, Socialists, and National Progressives. This government was hostile to the reactionary and fascist parties and strove to establish even closer relations with the Scandinavian countries.

The Turkey, Iraq, Iran, and Afghanistan signed a non-aggression pact, which established an Islamic entente to counter international tensions. This Islamic front offered the participating states an effective deterrent to the imperialistic designs of the European powers in the Middle East. The agreement secured the Asiatic region of Turkey as the Balkan Pact protected European Turkey. Turkey was recognized as the crucial force for peace in Eastern Europe and its prestige bolstered this Asiatic pact.
Vatican Recognition of Spanish Nationalist Government
Pope Pius XI, in response to the anti-clericalism of the Republican government, supported General Francisco Franco and formally recognized the Nationalist government in Spain.

As most of Europe was preoccupied with the German absorption of Austria, the Polish government issued a series of demands from the Lithuanians. Relations between the two countries remained bitter since the Polish seizure of Vilnius, and the Lithuanians refused to open their border with Poland. No progress was made to establish full relations. Faced with the threat of war, the Lithuanian government immediately agreed to all of the Polish demands, including recognition of the status quo in eastern Europe.
We must fold to their demands!
Troops from Ecuador and Peru clashed on the frontier over a border dispute between the two countries. The fighting threatened to escalate into a war over this long-standing dispute.
Canadian Withdrawal from the Gold Standard
The Canadian government decided to take the Canadian dollar off the gold standard in light of worsening international financial conditions.
The Bulgarian government arrested over a thousand Communists and Macedonians in an attempt to undermine further political disorder.

A major leader in the creation of the Polish army and government, Marshal Josef Pilsudski died and was succeeded by General Edward Smigly-Rydz as the commander of the Polish army. General Smigly-Rydz soon became the new power behind the country's presidential system.
Philippine voters elected Manuel Quezon as the first president of the Philippines, as well as a vice president and a national assembly.
Chiang Kai-shek was elected President of the Chinese Executive Committee.
The British and French governments announced that their navies had mined Norwegian waters in an effort to prevent German warships from passing through these waters.

During the German rearmament effort of the 1930s a need for additional mobile forces specially to support the precious Armour divisions was recognized by the OKW. The idea was to consolidate Trucks into formations, providing infantry the capability of keeping pace with the fast moving panzers.

This unit represents a hq consisting of your national leader and important political staff. Be aware that loss of this unit will lead to the death of your political unit. Therefore, it is highly recommend to do not engage this unit in any battle and leave it far away from the enemy.

The Brandenburg Regiment, part of Nazi Germanys special forces, was created by Captain Theodor von Hippel. Hippel's main idea was to form small groups of soldiers who would be not only very fluent in foreign languages, but also trained in methods of sabotage. They would then work from within the enemy and try their best to disrupt communication and logistics. One of the Brandenburg mens first major roles in World War II was their action in Poland. Before the German invasion they infiltrated the country, dressed as civilians, and during the night, took key points needed for the next days invasion to go smoothly. Moreover, the Brandenburgers served in Unternehmen Babarossa, southern Africa, Afghanistan, the Middle East and in the Caucasus.

In 1836, the Piedmontese Army adopted light infantry formations similar to the French chasseurs and Austrian jägers. Italys Bersaglieri regiments expanded to three battalions each during the Second World War, but the Army resisted temptations to water down their quality, and recruits had to be of above-average size and stamina. They endured intense physical training, just as their great-grandfathers had, and had to qualify as marksmen. The Bersaglieri fought in southern France and Greece in 1940 as well as in North Africa and on the Eastern Front.

In the late 1920s the navy began to form Special Naval Landing Forces as standing regiments (albeit of battalion size). These forces were raised at and took their names from the four main naval districts/bases in Japan: Kure, Maizuru, Sasebo, and Yokosuka. Initially, the SNLF were not a marine force, but was instead sailors who had basic infantry training and were employed in landings during the Russo-Japanese War and the Boxer Rebellion. Soon their training and equipment were improved upon drastically, and their forces were given a variety of other operations as well. Some units even were converted to parachute units. The SNLF personnel were well-trained, high quality troops with good morale and they performed well against opposition across Southeast Asia.

By late summer 1942, a unit of Americans and Canadians at Camp William Henry Harrison, near Helena, Mont., was training under the command of 35-year-old Colonel Frederick -the Devil's brigade was born. He envisioned three mini-regiments, each with about 800 men divided between two (instead of the usual three) battalions. For his troops, Frederick wanted recruits who were strong, intelligent and accustomed to working out of doors in the harshest conditions.He and his staff officers combed American units training in the Southwest and Pacific Northwest forsingle men between ages 21 and 35within the occupational range of lumberjacks, forest rangers, hunters, northwoodsmen, game wardens, prospectors, and explorers. The unit first saw action in the battle in Italy, expecially during battle of Anzio in 1944 the Devil's brigade demonstrated the value of their unique skills and training. In August 1944 the Devil's brigade took part in the invasion of southern France during Operation Dragoon and beeing disbanded in 1945.

The People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs (NKVD) was a law enforcement agency of the Soviet Union that directly executed the will of the All-Union Communist Party. It was closely associated with the Soviet secret police, which at times was part of the agency, and is known for its political repression during the era of Joseph Stalin. The NKVD contained the regular, public police force of the USSR, including traffic police, firefighting, border guards and archives. It is best known for the activities of the Gulag and the Main Directorate for State Security, the predecessor of the KGB. The NKVD conducted mass extrajudicial executions, ran the Gulag system of forced labor camps and suppressed underground resistance, and was responsible for mass deportations of entire nationalities and Kulaks to unpopulated regions of the country. It was also tasked with protection of Soviet borders and espionage, which included political assassinations abroad, influencing foreign governments and enforcing Stalinist policy within communist movements in other countries.
Occupation Policy in Belgium and Netherlands

After the success of the invasion, a military administration was established in Belgium as well as in the Netherlands, bringing the territory under the direct rule of the Wehrmacht. Thousands of Belgian and Dutch soldiers were taken as prisoners of war, and many were not released until 1945. The German administration juggled competing objectives of maintaining order while extracting material from the territory for the war effort. They were assisted by the local civil service, which believed that limited co-operation with the occupiers would result in the least damage to their home countrie's interests.\n \nBelgian Fascist parties in both Flanders and Wallonia as well as National Socialist Movement in the Netherlands, established before the war, collaborated much more actively with the occupiers. They helped recruit volunteers for the German army and were given more power themselves toward the end of the occupation. Food and fuel were tightly rationed, and all official news was closely censored. From 1942, the occupation became more repressive. Jews suffered systematic persecution and deportation to concentration camps, as measures were taken against potential political opposition. Despite vigorous protest, the Germans deported civilians to work in factories in Germany, which led to a vast expansion of the local resistance movement.

After the successful landing of the German Wehrmacht in the USA, a surrender of the allied troops was just a matter of time. Although some US soldiers still continued to fight the overwhelming German army, most had already surrendered. In order to break the morale of the US soldiers as well as showing the superiority of the German Reich, Hitler ordered the destruction of Mount Rushmore. Today, at 12:00 a.m German engineers ignited the explosives and successfully levelled Mount Rushmore to the ground. What a great day for the Reich

The US army was completely surprised by the German landing operation and could build up only little resistance. Soon, important cities fell into German hands including New York, center of the the country's financial and commerce services.\n \nToday, a spectacular show was put on by the invading troops parading down the streets of New York to the roaring sound of German jet fighters passing by overhead. Even more spectacular were the massive mechanical beasts of the German Wehrmacht. The parade was broadcasted and watched by more than 100 million people, making it the largest audience number of all time.

Today, the incredible German army was able to capture Washington. Although suffering some casualties due to heavy US resistance, Skorzeny and his brave men were able to capture the American capital and raised the German flag. This is a historical day for the German Reich, soon the whole world will belong to us!

As the first German scout units advance into the city, the chimes of Big Ben echo throughout the deserted streets of London. The sound is soon drowned out by sporadic small-arms fire, before the bell itself is forever silenced by a German tank round.\n \nFallschirmjäger storm Buckingham Palace, but the Royal Family has already been evacuated well in advance of the attack. Still, the Union Jack is lowered and the German flag hosted in its place. London has fallen.

The Führerbunker was an air-raid shelter located near the Reich Chancellery in Berlin, Germany.  It was part of a subterranean bunker complex which was constructed in two major phases, one part in 1936 and the other in 1943.  Hitler took up residence in the Führerbunker on 16 January 1945 and it became the epicentre of the Nazi regime until the last week of World War II.  Hitler married Eva Braun here during the last week of April 1945, shortly before they committed suicide

During Operation Olive, the major Allied offensive in the autumn of 1944, which commenced on 25 August, the Gothic Line defences were penetrated on both the Eighth Army and Fifth Army fronts, but there was no decisive breakthrough. Churchill had hoped that a major advance in the autumn of 1944 would open the way for the Allied armies to advance north eastwards through the 'Ljubljana Gap' to Vienna and Hungary to forestall the Russians advancing into Eastern Europe.

In the six months following the D-Day landings in Normandy in June 1944, the American and British armies advanced to the Rhine and seemed poised to strike into the heart of Germany, while the Soviet Army, advancing from the east through Poland, reached the Oder. It seemed likely that Berlin would soon fall and Germany be divided. In these circumstances, it occurred both to some leading figures in the German regime and to the Allies that the logical thing for the Germans to do would be to move the government to the mountainous areas of southern Germany and Austria, where a relatively small number of determined troops could hold out for some time. A number of intelligence reports to the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Forces identified the area held stores of foodstuffs and military supplies built up over the preceding six months, and could even be harbouring armaments production facilities. Within this fortified terrain, they said, Hitler would be able to evade the Allies and cause tremendous difficulties for the occupying Allied forces throughout Germany.
A Soviet rocket with a hybrid engine, GIRD-09, designed under leadership of Mikhail Tikhonravov is launched in Nakhabino, reaching an altitude of 400 meters.

Socialist realism is a teleologically-oriented style of art having its purpose the furtherance of the goals of socialism and communism. The State, after the Congress of 1934, laid down four rules for what became known as 'Socialist Realism' That the work can be Proletarian art relevant to the workers and understandable to them. Typical scenes of everyday life of the people. Realistic in the representational sense. Partisan supportive of the aims of the State and the Party.

The Soviet invasion of Xinjiang was a military campaign in the Chinese northwestern region of Xinjiang in 1934. Two Soviet Russian GPU brigades, consisting of about 7,000 troops backed by tanks, planes, and artillery, attacked the 36th division near Tutung. The battle raged for several weeks on the frozen Tutung River. Both sides suffered heavy casualties before Ma Zhongying ordered his division to withdraw.

The Soviet invasion of Xinjiang was a military campaign in the Chinese northwestern region of Xinjiang in 1934. Two Soviet Russian GPU brigades, consisting of about 7,000 troops backed by tanks, planes, and artillery, attacked the 36th division near Tutung. The battle raged for several weeks on the frozen Tutung River. Both sides suffered heavy casualties before Ma Zhongying ordered his division to withdraw. So, the Soviets received the province of Guhjla from Xinjiang.

The Sino-Soviet Nonaggression Pact was signed in Nanjing between the Republic of China and the USSR during the Second Sino-Japanese War. It was registered in League of Nations Treaty Series on September 8, 1937. At first the treaty led to improving relations between the Kuomintang, Chiang Kai-shek's government and the USSR. The pact contributed to the worsening relationship between China and Germany, which culminated in the end of German military assistance in China.

The Czech and Soviet governments signed a pact of mutual assistance and an air convention. Under the terms of the agreement, the Soviet Union promised to come to the aid of Czechoslovakia in the event of an attack, provided that the French did so as well. While this pact bolstered Czechoslovakia's position in case of a war with Germany, it led to a great deal of resentment in Germany. The Germans accused the Czechs of making their country a base for Russian air operations against Germany.

To support the Greek government, the British sent an expeditionary force to Crete and other Greek islands. In addition, the Soviet government sent 134 fighter aircraft to the Greeks to help stem the Italian invasion.

The Ilyushin Il-2 was a ground-attack aircraft in the WW2, produced by the Soviet Union in very large numbers. In combination with its successor it is the single most produced military aircraft design in all of aviation history, as well as one of the most produced piloted aircraft. Tactics improved as Soviet aircrew became used to the Il-2's strengths. Instead of a low horizontal straight approach, the target was usually kept to the pilot's left and a turn and shallow dive of 30 degrees was utilized.

The Soviet Volunteer Group was the ostensibly volunteer Soviet Air Forces to support the Republic of China during the Second Sino-Japanese War between 1937 and 1941. After the Marco Polo Bridge Incident, the Sino-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact was signed and large Soviet support was given to China by the Soviet Union, including the volunteer squadrons. Some 450 Soviet pilots and technicians brougth 155 fighter aircraft, 62 bombers, and 8 trainers into China. The Soviet squadrons were withdrawn in 1941.
Sale of Russian interest in Chinese Eastern Railway

The Soviet government sold its interest in the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchukuo for 140 million yen, finalizing negotiations which began in May 1933. This sale helped reduce tensions between Japan and the Soviet Union over Manchurian affairs, but problems continued to persist due to Japanese activity on the border of Outer Mongolia. Outer Mongolia had an alliance with the Soviet Union and was under Russian protection.

EODAIP is a gameplay-focused HoI 2 mod based on Edge of Darkness, Edge of Darkness was created to deliver the definitive 1933 scenario for Darkest Hour. Hundreds of new flavor events, decisions, all new graphics and special units have all been designed with a realistic, historic focus that will be sure to reward those that have a passion for the history of the Second World War and teach even the most well-read armchair historian fascinating new information about this definitive event of the 20th century. EODAIP adds detailed and flexible scripts that aim to recreate various historical or proposed military strategies, re-balances various parts of the game, and focuses on letting the AI to "play" Hearts of Iron against you, instead of spawning infinite divisions from events.\n For any feedback, please contact me on the Paradox forums.

After fall of important Soviet cities, Germany quickly started a diplomatic campaign with Japan. As the Soviet army had redeployed most of their Manchurian divisions to defend against the onslaught of the German army, Japan could easily occupy important cities in the east which would significantly reduce the morale of the Red Army and force the Soviet Union into a two-front war. In a mutual agreement between our two states, Japan would be promised territorial gains in the far east while we would pledge military support and bring them into a formal alliance with us.

After the successful invasion and liberation of far-east Siberia from the suppressing Soviet Union by our overwhelming army, we are now able to bring this land into cultivation by incorporating it into Manchuko.

The old battleship Hessen, in the same prededing class of the Schleswig-Holstein and Schlesien. The ship is currently decommissioned and in disrepair. We can either recommission her or break her up for scrap.

The Heimwehr was a nationalist paramilitary group operating within Austria similar to Germany's Freikorps. In 1936 the Heimwehr was usurped into the Fatherland's Front on decree of Chancellor Kurt von Schuschnigg and replaced by a militia supposedly less inclined towards uproar against the regime, the Frontmiliz. Politically, they suffered a decline in support and significance due to the pan-German, nationalist allure of the Nazis and Italy's gradual reorientation of its foreign policy towards Germany.
Recognition of the Nationalist Spanish Government

Our government officially recognized General Franco's government as the new regime. The British and French governments continued to maintain their embargo on military supplies to the Republican government and attempted to organize the other powers to embrace a policy of non-intervention in the Spanish Civil War. They drew up a supervision scheme, but the plan proved ineffective as powers who wished to participate in the fighting ignored the agreement.

During the 1930s there were two main schools of thought in the Kriegsmarine. Grossadmiral Raeder and many other officers argued for a large surface fleet based on the Z-plan.  On the other hand, Kapitan z. See Karl Dönitz proposed a force of several hundred u-boats and a minimal surface fleet.  In the end Admiral Raeder won the argument and the ambitious Z-plan was commenced.  Dönitz was forced to settle for a small force of u-boats and was named Führer der Unterseeboote (FdU) in early 1936.
Appoint Captain Dönitz as FdU and let him test his theories.
The surface fleet is a waste of time. Let Dönitz assume command.
Admiral Raeder is right, u-boats are a waste of resources.

After his appointment as FdU, Captain Dönitz worked tirelessly to expand the u-boat arm. U-boats secretly undertook combat actions against Republican Spanish forces and a number of new boats were ordered. In order to expedite training for the crews, Captain Dönitz advises removing some of our costal U-boats from front line operations to expand the U-boat school.
We don't need a U-boat School

After war erupted with the USSR, the OKW directed the Kriegsmarine to develop a plan for interdicting shipping in the Black Sea. BdU-Ops developed a plan for transporting a flotilla of Type IIB boats to Tulcea via special rail and canal shipments.
We don't need u-boats in the Black Sea
After many months of preparations the 30. Unterseebootsflotilla is now ready to commence combat operations from the new base in Tulcea.
The 30. Unterseebootsflotilla at Constanta is ready for action

Many of the Wehrmacht's soldiers were high when they went into battle, especially against Poland and France -- in a Blitzkrieg fueled by speed. The German military was supplied with millions of methamphetamine tablets during the first half of 1940. The drugs were part of a plan to help pilots, sailors and infantry troops become capable of superhuman performance. The military leadership liberally dispensed such stimulants, but also alcohol and opiates, as long as it believed drugging and intoxicating troops could help it achieve victory over the Allies. But the Nazis were less than diligent in monitoring side-effects like drug addiction and a decline in moral standards.

Operation Barbarossa has not met its expected timetable and the Soviet Union continues to resist our advance. Our oil supplies are under critical pressure and it is time that a new strategy was developed to meet this challenge. If we were to successfully invade and occupy Turkey, this would give us another front to invade the Caucasus mountain ranges from the south and later apply pressure to the British in the Middle East, though the costs of this invasion should be strongly considered before we decide to take this course of action.\n \nAlthough "Operation Gertrude" never took place in reality, this hypothetical strategy was supposedly abandoned from its initial conception in the summer of 1942 due to the challenges of Case Blue and Allied landings in Sicily. The concept of "Pan-Turkism" between Turkey and Azerbaijan was also seen as a threat by German leadership during this time and it was considered to be in the Reich's interest to ensure that nationalistic movements in the Middle East fell under their sphere of influences to ensure their vision of the New Order was achieved fully.

The Great Liberation, or as the outside world would call it, the Second Sino-Japanese War has come to an end. Like the righteous blade of the Samurai against a common brigand, the Imperial Japanese Army has severed the head of Nationalist China.  With this decisive victory, the Chinese people are now safeguarded against European imperialism. In the historic Chinese capital of Nanjing, a conclusive peace treaty has been signed between Hirohito's entourage and our specially chosen leaders for the Republic of China-Nanjing. With Wang Jingwe as its head of state, their legality as the legitimate representative of all Chinese peoples has been recognized by the signatories of the Anti-Comintern Pact.
 
Triumphant parades march through Tokyo, the banner of The Rising Sun adorning every building. Children and adults alike wave their flags with an overwhelming sense of pride.  Cherry blossoms flutter through the city as smiling girls throw flowers at the marching Imperial Japanese Army. The IJA and IJN have set aside their animosity, and the Japanese Navy stages demonstrations in the harbor in a display of national strength and unity. Tokyo's residents look on in awe, the victory emboldening their belief in our divine mission. Our vision of the Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere is becoming a reality!
 
Yet now is not the time to rest - many challenges still lie ahead. Though the war in China is over, the population is restless and it will take great effort to suppress the remaining resistance. The Europeans still need to be removed from the Pacific, and the USSR eyes us with growing suspicion in the cold reaches of Siberia. Today, however, the Japanese people celebrate their greatest victory. With the guiding light of the Rising Sun, we will lead all of Asia into a glorious future!

Chongqing served as the wartime capital for the Nationalist Chinese forces during the Second Sino-Japanese War. Chiang Kai-shek designated the city as the Chinese state's provisional capital during the war due to its highly defensible position nestled between China's great mountain ranges and intersecting rivers in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. When the Japanese invaded in 1937, much of China's heavy industry was relocated to Chongqing and neighboring cities such as Chengdu, making the city a critical nexus of the Chinese war effort against Imperial Japan. Historically, the Japanese never penetrated far enough into China to threaten this vital city.\n \nToday, the Imperial Japanese Army storms across the Yangtze river as the Chinese resistance shatters before their relentless advance. Hastily erected defenses in the mountain ranges surrounding the city and destruction of bridges on the waterways have failed to stop the advancing IJA forces, and the city has been overrun. Millions of Chinese refugees flee the city, many of them from the already conquered provinces of the eastern heartland. Chiang Kai-shek and his entourage have vanished, possibly killed in the onslaught. The banner of the Rising Sun flutters proudly as the sun sets over the once beautiful Chinese "city on rivers", which now lies in ruins. The core of the Chinese resistance has been annihilated and our victory is now inevitable!

The Chinese city of Hong Kong was ceded to the British Empire in 1841 and established as one of its Crown colonies. The humiliation of the Chinese at the conclusion of the First Opium War resulted in the cession of the city in the Treaty of Nanjing. For the first time in China's long history, it was forced to give up territory to foreigners from the other side of the world.\n \nToday, this historical injustice has been rectified and Hong Kong is now in the hands of its rightful owners, the great leaders of a glorious Asian destiny - the Empire of Japan. The despised Union Jack is lowered for the last time as the Rising Sun takes its place. This decisive blow to British pride will surely let them know that we are on our way to removing their imperialistic influence from all of Asia!
We have expelled the British from China!

Singapore was described by the British as the 'Gibraltar in the East'. The city served as a vital base for the British defensive 'Singapore strategy' in the Pacific, and was considered a vital harbor and geostrategic location. The possibility of a Japanese conquest of the city was not taken as a credible threat by the British war leadership.\n \nAfter the attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, the British felt that Singapore would become a likely next target for a Japanese attack. When the Japanese advanced on the city through the Malaya peninsula in February of 1942, Commonwealth forces were forced to retreat. The subsequent capture of Singapore would be labeled by Winston Churchill as the 'largest capitulation' in British military history, and showed the Allied powers that Japan was to be taken seriously as a military power. The surrender of Singapore was the largest surrender of British-led forces in history, with 80,000 Commonwealth forces captured as prisoners of war.
We have humiliated the British! Onwards to India!

Vladivostok, loosely translated as 'the ruler of the East', is a key Russian port city that was acquired from Qing China in 1860 in the Treaty of Beijing. The Russian Empire expelled most of its native inhabitants throughout the course of the 19th century and invested heavily into its growth. The city became the end-point for the Trans-Siberian Railway, making it a critical hub for commerce and transportation between European Russia and its far eastern possessions.
 
During the Second World War, the Allies sent about 18,000,000 tons of material aid to the Soviet Union, half of which went through the Pacific Ocean with Vladivostok receiving the bulk of these shipments.
 
Japanese soldiers storm the unaware Soviet garrison at Vladivostok, quickly overwhelming them before they can call for reinforcements. With the seizure of this key city, Soviet influence in the area has been seriously curtailed. It is time to restore Machuria to its rightful owners and correct more historical injustices wrought upon the Asian peoples by European imperialism!

The Reichskriegsflagge now flies over the Atlantic Ocean, and the Greater German Reich's influence now spans from the Pacific to the Atlantic, a continental dream that has surpassed even the Manifest Destiny of the United States.

Calcutta, nicknamed as the 'City of Joy' or 'Cultural Capital of India', is the principal commercial and cultural center of East India. While the city did not come under direct threat of invasion during the war, there was genuine fear growing in the city that the Japanese would target it next after their successful invasion of Burma in 1942. The decision of an American bank to relocate to Bombay triggered a wave of speculation that the United States had asked its citizens to evacuate the city. After the Second World War, it would become the center of activity of the Indian independence movement.\n \nJapanese forces have attained control of the city after a lightning-quick invasion from the east and support from marine forces in the Bay of Bengal. Local British radio chatter is full of confusion and panic at the fall of this vital city along the Ganges. The capture of this ancient city is yet another message to the world that the Rising Sun will stop at nothing it its divine mission to liberate Asia from the tyranny of European oppression!
Onwards, to Delhi! We must unseat the British Raj!
